awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Ruthenium Catalyzed Reactions Leading to New Polymer Architectures and Improved Chemical Recyclability of Plastics
awd_abstract_narration:
Plastics are made from polymers and polymer manufacture represents one of the largest and most dynamic sectors of the chemical industry. Companies are targeting better performing polymer materials derived from more economical and environmentally friendly (bio-renewable) feedstocks. These improvements are often driven by chemical advancements in polymer synthesis research, such as the work supported by this award. It is critical to the field of polymer chemistry to improve the basic understanding of the relationships between polymer structure and the properties of the resulting plastic, which is a primary goal of this research.  Undergraduate students, including low income and first generation college students, perform laboratory work for this study and receive valuable training to prepare them for graduate school and/or employment in the chemical industry. 

With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Prof. Robertson of Northland College and Prof. Carney of the University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire conduct collaborative research to better understand the properties of ruthenium catalysts in polymerization reactions.  Specifically, this project focuses on making advancements in five key areas: (1) preparation of polymers from bio-renewable monomers, such as 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), (2) polymer alternatives to polyurethanes (found in many paints, varnishes, adhesives, and foams), (3) increasing the utility of commodity plastics, (4) depolymerization methods to produce useful chemicals from waste plastics, and (5) synthesis of new ruthenium compounds to better understand the impacts of chemical structure on the catalyst's performance.  Toward this end, the research team is synthesizing and studying new ruthenium catalysts with structurally versatile N-phosphinoamidine and beta-diketimine ligand backbones.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit.

The primary outcome of the project was the development of synthetic methods for the synthesis of polyureas and polycycloacetals, two classes of polymeric materials that are formed from readily available building blocks (monomers) and often with high levels of biorenewable content. A new method for the chemical recycling of polyesters is also under development.

Diglycerol, one of the monomers used in the polycycloacetal syntheses, is readily prepared from glycerol. This biorenewable building block is produced in large quantities as a co-product during biodiesel production. To date, the commercial market for glycerol has not kept pace with its production. However, the potential large-scale use of diglycerol in the synthesis of polycycloacetals may provide a valuable outlet for this inexpensive and readily available starting material. For the polycycloacetals, the polymers displayed a wide range of commercially useful properties - from rigid to flexible to elastomeric - with the properties being tunable based on the amounts and types of monomers used. For both classes of polymers, the synthetic procedures were designed to be reversible, meaning that the polymers could conceivably be chemically recycled into their constituent monomers for reuse, thereby reducing the environmental impact of the polymers.

The results of the polyurea and polycycloacetal work were disseminated to the scientific community via poster presentations at a national meeting of the American Chemical Society in 2018 and the 2019 Green Chemistry and Engineering conference, respectively. The polycycloacetal work was also published in the Journal of Applied Polymer Science in December 2019.

A second outcome of the project was the design and synthesis of transition metal compounds to serve as potential hydrogenation and dehydrogenation catalysts. These complexes were screened for hydrogenation/dehydrogenation activity. Several of the transition metal compounds were structurally characterized by x-ray crystallography, which confirmed their identities.

Broader Impacts.

A third important outcome of the award was the training and professional development provided to undergraduate researchers. The research team consisted of two students at UW-Eau Claire and thirteen students at Northland College. The Northland College research team learned state-of-the-art synthetic and characterization techniques that enabled them to test thousands of different reaction conditions and substrates. Hundreds of optimized reaction products were transported to the UW-Eau Claire team for polymer characterization and mechanical property analyses. In addition, several undergraduate members of the research team gained valuable experience by serving as the primary presenters of their results at national research conferences; and the collaborative nature of this NSF project drew upon the complementary expertise of the principal investigators and exposed the undergraduates to a wider range of chemistries and research approaches than if the project had been a single investigator award.

At Northland College, five of the 13 students have graduated and moved on to careers in industry or education, three of the 13 are currently in graduate school (University of Guelph, Marquette University and Michigan Technological University). Of the remaining five currently enrolled students, one is actively applying to graduate programs, and the others are still considering various career options.


Last Modified: 12/22/2020
Modified by: Nicholas Robertson
